Babb, Claude Robert
Meadow Lake,
To Sask. - March, 1973.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A WITNESS TESTIMONY TO THE HISTORY OF SASKATCHEWAN'S PIONEER EXPERIENCES

It is difficult to measure a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual has enough experience to know what it was like. It is impossible for anyone to answer all questions. Some may be impossible to answer at all; others may not apply to your experiences. Others may prove impossible to answer because they don't apply to your experiences. Others may prove impossible to answer because there is not sufficient space to answer them. Others may be impossible to answer because there is not sufficient space to answer them. Others may be impossible to answer because there is not sufficient space to answer them.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1944, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write their answers separately.

Other Questions:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Days: What Did We Do?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here and you will be sent a copy.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. These are listed below. Please make sure the ones you will be willing to answer.

All questionnaires:
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer school life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer church life
- Pioneer education and schoolwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaire

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
Babb, Claude Robert
Headley Lake,
To Sask. - March, 1931.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A NOTE OF APPRECIATION TO THE PIONEERS

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES Q251272/251280/251281

No. 2

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life's because no individual who is asked to answer it has had exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions which are asked may apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer; so do not worry about leaving blank spaces. The best thing to do is to answer all questions which apply to you; if they do not apply, simply leave them blank.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write their names on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questions:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1 entitled "Pioneer Days: What We Remember" Canadian Pioneer Days is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and you will be sent one.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a future date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires:

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life
- Pioneer building and chorework
- Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed Questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

PIONEER EXPERIENCES; A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you have not written the name correctly, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: C. A. RADE ROBERT BABBE.
2. Your address: M.E.A.D.O.W. LAKE, SASK.
3. Date: JULY 17, 1957.
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) MILL GROVE, MISSOURI, U.S.A.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? ROBERT BABBE MERCHANT.
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) MARCH 6, 1913.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. FIRTH AND LINCOLN, NEBR, U.S.A. FROM 1903 TO 1913.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West? TO DO ORCHESTRAL WORK, THEN DECIDED TO HOMESTEAD.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) THROUGH OTHER PEOPLE.

1. Your full name: C. RAUDE ROBERT BABBE

3. Date: JUNE 17, 1954

5. What was your father's name and occupation? ROBERT BABBE MERCHANT

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. FIRTH AND LITCOLEY, TIEBR, U.S.A. FROM 1903 TO 1913

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you were under 18 years of age when you came)

9. What were your reasons for coming West? TO DO ORCHESTRAL WORK, THEN DECIDED TO HOMESTEAD.

10. How did you learn about the West? THROUGH OTHER PEOPLE
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

There opinions were varied.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

With friends, family came late.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Railway

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement)

Note

15. Where did you first stop when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

With Dati Roundy, Truax, Sask.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Near Truax, Sask.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Moose Jaw, Avonlea, Francis, Tywatt, Weyburn, Meota, Indian Head, Grand Forks, B.C., and Meadow Lake,

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Farm work, ranch, dance playing, and base ball.

WEYBURLT, MEOTA, INDIAN HEAD,

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Just the usual. Working over, digging stone, and breaking prairie.

only as a full player, or dance violist, with in a radius of thirty-five miles; mostly teams until around 1915. Then some times by car.
